review.title: Critical Survey of the Freely Available Arabic Corpora
review.abstract: The availability of corpora is a major factor in building natural language processing applications. However, the costs of acquiring corpora can prevent some researchers from going further in their endeavours. The ease of access to freely available corpora is urgent needed in the NLP research community especially for language such as Arabic. Currently, there is not easy was to access to a comprehensive and updated list of freely available Arabic corpora. We present in this paper, the results of a recent survey conducted to identify the list of the freely available Arabic corpora and language resources. Our preliminary results showed an initial list of 66 sources. We presents our findings in the various categories studied and we provided the direct links to get the data when possible.

sections.heading: 4.1 Raw Text Corpora
sections.text: In this section we quote 23 freely available raw text corpora, i.e. they do not contain any comments and are limited to the text files themselves. Raw text corpora are divided into four categories listed below.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Monolingual Corpora
sections.text: The 11 freely available monolingual corporas found are all available for download (Table 1), most of them covering the news section, and they are large corporas ranging from 1 million to 113 million words. Other corporas cover other areas such as student essays (Farawaneh) and classical Arabic (KSU Corpus of Classical Arabic and Tashkeela). sections.heading: 4.1.2. Multilingual Corpora
sections.text: Among the corpora listed in Table 2, we can consider the UN corpus to be the most important and best known free corpus in its category. The Meedan, with 1 million words of Arabic / English-oriented sentences, is also a very valuable resource. The Standard hadith corpus and the Koran Arabic / English-oriented corpus included in the Egyptian translation tool are lesser known resources that could be used in any work related to the religious field.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. Dialectal Corpora
sections.text: The two dialect corporas listed in Table 3 are very valuable, mainly because editing the Arabic dialect is a relatively recent task and there is a real need for such resources. Tunisian Dialect Corpus (Graja et al.) is a transcribed spoken dialect corpus consisting of 1,465 statements by railway staff and 1,615 customer comments. Recent work by (Almeman and Lee 2013) can be considered an important contribution to the advancement of Arabic dialect resources, with 2 million unique words collected online on 55k websites covering four major Arabic dialects (Gulf, Levantine, North Africa, Egypt).

sections.heading: 4.1.4. Web-based Corpora
sections.text: In this category, we have placed some corpora (Table 4) that are available exclusively online through an online query interface, so that no data is provided for download that may be inconvenient for some research studies. sections.heading: 4.2 Annotated Corpora
sections.text: Commented corpora are very useful to build systems and tools based on monitored algorithms, and the free availability of resources will help young researchers train and build systems at minimal cost. In this section we list a selection of freely available named corpora units, corpora with error comments, and several different corpora with comments, including part of the speech (POS) commented corpora, syntactically and semantically commented corpora.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Error-Annotated Corpora
sections.text: Error-annotated corpora can be very useful for corpus-based error studies and also for building automatic spell-checking tools. Table 6 lists three resources, QALB and the corpus for Arabic learners are still ongoing efforts. The KACST error corpus (Alkanhal et al. 2012) consists exclusively of student essays that are corrected manually, while Alfifi et al. (2013) will include the correction of errors as well as the categories of errors. When finished, Zaghouani et al. (2014) corpus will be the only 2M words that can be corrected for Arabic with four types of text: essays by native and non-native students, online posts, and corrected English / Arabic machine translation.

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Miscellaneous Annotated Corpora
sections.text: Most of these resources allow direct download, with the exception of OntoNotes, which are available free of charge from the LDC. The OntoNotes corpus (Weischedel et al. 2013) comprises various text genres (news, telephone conversations, weblogs, usenet newsgroups, broadcasts, talk shows) in three languages (English, Chinese, and Arabic) with structural information (syntax and predicate argument structure) and flat semantics (literally linked to ontology and co-reference). A notable effort in this category is the ongoing work on building the corpus of Quranic Arabic, an annotated linguistic resource consisting of 77,430 words of Koranic Arabic. The project aims to provide morphological and syntactical annotations for researchers who wish to study the language of the corpus.

sections.heading: 4.3 Lexicon
sections.text: In this section we describe some available lexical databases and word lists. Most of these resources are available for download, some lexicographs are part of tools and systems, but since these tools are open source, these lexicographs can be used for research purposes.

sections.heading: 4.3.1. Lexical Databases
sections.text: Fortunately, most of them are free, such as version 1.0 of the well-known Buckwalter Morphological Analyzer (Buckwalter 2002), and other important efforts have been adapted from English to Arabic, such as Arabic WordNet (Elkateb et al. 2006) and Arabic VerbNet (Mousser 2010). In Arabic WordNet, words are grouped into synonym sentences, providing general definitions and the various semantic relationships between synonym sentences. Arabic VerbNet provides a lexicon that classifies the most commonly used Arabic verbs and provides their syntactic and semantic information.

sections.heading: 4.4 Speech Corpora
sections.text: To the best of our knowledge, the corpus in Table 10, compiled by Almeman and Lee (2013), is the only freely available Arabic language corpus. Most of the currently available corpus are available from the LDC or ELRA with membership fees.

sections.heading: 4.5 Handwriting Recognition Corpora
sections.text: Here, too, the corpora for manuscript recognition in Arabic are very rare and usually available at cost price. An exception are the four corpora in Table 11, which can be used for various NLP tasks from OCR to writer identification.

sections.heading: 4.6 Miscellaneous Corpora types
sections.text: The list in Table 12 presents seven corporas that are useful for a variety of tasks related to NLP, such as answering questions to Ben Ajiba et al. (2007) and Trigui et al. (2010), plagiarism detection to Bensalem et al. (2013), summary of documents to El-Haj et al. (2010) and El-Haj and Rayson (2013), comparable text detection to Saad et al. (2013). Finally, the multi-purpose corpus of Kalimat (El-Haj and Koulali (2013) is a unique corpus that includes about 20k of news wire words extracted for summaries, marked as entities, tagged as part of the language, and morphologically analyzed.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: The goal behind this study is to promote the use of free corpora, especially by those who cannot afford membership or high fees, to acquire a corpora from a language data center. Results showed that many of the freely available resources for Arabic are not always visible and are therefore hard to find by potential users.
